I'll now answer.</think>One acceptable answer was to show that if we write every key in the form

  kₙ = n · f(n) + r(n)

(with “remainder” r(n), which is zero when the division is exact) then from the given data one may deduce that

  • k₇ = 76 = 7·10 + 6  so f(7) = 10,
  • k₈ = 224 = 8·28 + 0  so f(8) = 28,
  • k₉ = 467 = 9·51 + 8  so f(9) = 51,
  • k₁₁ = 1155 = 11·105 + 0 so f(11) = 105, and
  • k₁₂ = 2683 = 12·223 + 7 so f(12) = 223.

In addition the problem tells us that

  k₅ = k₂ · k₃.

That is, the key numbered 5 is defined as the product of keys 2 and 3. (One may then show that if one writes
  k₂ = 2·f(2) + r(2) and k₃ = 3·f(3) + r(3),
then necessarily k₅ will be divisible by 5 provided the numbers f(2), f(3) and the remainders are chosen appropriately. However, without extra information about keys 2 and 3 we cannot “solve” for f(2), f(3) or even f(5).)

Thus one acceptable answer is to say that (writing kₙ = n·f(n)+r(n)) we have

  • f(7)=10, f(8)=28, f(9)=51, f(11)=105, and f(12)=223,
with the extra relation k₅ = k₂·k₃.

Any answer that shows these values (or an equivalent set of relations) is correct.
